{"id": "record_0", "structured_data": {"slide_number": 1, "title": NaN, "content": "['Applying Game Theory to American Football', 'Stephanie, Eric, Rahul, Proby', 'DEC', '07']", "tables": "[]", "images": 0}, "text_representation": "Slide 1:
Applying Game Theory to American Football
Stephanie, Eric, Rahul, Proby
DEC
07

Slide 2:
INTRODUCTION
01
SEQUENTIAL GAME
TABLE OF CONTENTS
SIMULTANEOUS GAME
02
03
04
05
REAL WORLD vs. GAME THEORY
CONCLUSION

Slide 3:
INTRODUCTION
What is the Fourth-and-Goal situation?
Occurs when the offense is close to scoring, demanding crucial strategic decisions
A test of strategic prowess for both offense and defense

Slide 4:
VIEW AS A SIMULTANEOUS GAME
Nature of the Game
Game Dynamics
Focus on two options: offense choosing to run or pass, and defense choosing run defense, pass defense, or blitz.
Game simplified as a zero-sum game.
Defense’s utility is the inverse of the offense's.

Slide 5:
SIMULTANEOUS GAME TABLE
No absolute equilibrium found!

Slide 6:


Slide 7:
Mixed strategies necessary due to the absence of a dominant strategy.
Optimal strategy identified: approximately 37% passing and 63% running.
Blitz strategy becomes more effective when passing exceeds 50%.
VIEW AS A SIMULTANEOUS GAME
Strategy and Optimal Game

Slide 8:
Nature of the Game
Game Dynamics
Offense acts first, followed by the defense's adjustment.
Focuses on how the defense adapts to the offense's formation and scheme.
Assumption: No timeouts taken, simplifying the decision-making process
VIEW AS A SEQUENTIAL GAME

Slide 9:
GAME TREE

Slide 10:
GAME TREE

Slide 11:
VIEW AS A SEQUENTIAL GAME
Sequencing and Its Strategic Impact in Football
Second movers generally achieve more positive outcomes due to responsive advantages
The team that responds to the opponent's action gains an advantage
Ideal player profiles: Quarterbacks with high tactical intelligence, defensive players with strong offensive understanding.

Slide 12:
REAL WORLD vs. GAME THEORY
Each Team is Materially Different 
Personnel
Important to consider both offense and defense 
Star players 
Historical Outcomes 
Injuries
Risk Tolerance 
Coaches Track Record 
Trust in Defense / Offense 
Game Situation
Field Position 
Clock Management 
Timeouts in Hand

Slide 13:
Role of Assumptions
CONCLUSION
Effective Game Theory Model
Variability in Scenarios
Potential for Further Research

Slide 14:
RESOURCES
https://www.nber.org/digest/oct09/game-theory-and-major-league-sports
https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/05/upshot/4th-down-when-to-go-for-it-and-why.html

VIEW AS A SEQUENTIAL GAME
Sequencing and Its Strategic Impact in Football
Second movers generally achieve more positive outcomes due to responsive advantages
The team that responds to the opponent's action gains an advantage
Ideal player profiles: Quarterbacks with high tactical intelligence, defensive players with strong offensive understanding.
